t: Proverbs 23
When*pn you sit down to dine with a ruler, consider*ln carefully what is before you,
and*ln put a knife to your throat if*ln you have a big appetite;
don’t*ln desire his choice food, for*ln that food is deceptive.
Don’t*pn wear yourself out to get rich; because*ln you know better, stop!
As*ln soon as your eyes fly to it, it disappears, for*ln it makes wings for itself and*ln flies like an eagle to the sky.
Don’t*pn eat a stingy person’s bread, and*ln don’t desire his choice food,
for*ln it’s like someone calculating inwardly. “Eat*ln and drink,” he says to you, but*ln his heart is not with you.
You*ln will vomit the little you’ve eaten and*ln waste your pleasant words.
Don’t*pn speak to a fool, for*ln he will despise the insight of your words.
Don’t*pn move an ancient boundary marker, and*ln don’t encroach on the fields of the fatherless,
for*ln their Redeemer is strong, and*ln he will champion their cause against you.
Apply*pn yourself to discipline and*ln listen to words of knowledge.
Don’t*pn withhold discipline from a youth; if*ln you punish him with a rod, he will not die.
Punish*ln him with a rod, and*ln you will rescue his life from Sheol.
My*pn son, if your heart is wise, my*ln heart will indeed rejoice.
My*ln innermost being will celebrate when*ln your lips say what is right.
Don’t*pn let your heart envy sinners; instead,*ln always fear the Lord.*s
For*ln then you will have a future, and*ln your hope will not be dashed.
Listen,*pn my son, and be wise; keep*ln your mind on the right course.
Don’t*ln associate with those who drink too much wine or*ln with those who gorge themselves on meat.
For*ln the drunkard and the glutton will become poor, and*ln grogginess will clothe them in rags.
Listen*pn to your father who gave you life, and*ln don’t despise your mother when she is old.
Buy — and*ln do not sell — truth, wisdom,*ln instruction, and understanding.
The*ln father of a righteous son will rejoice greatly, and*ln one who fathers a wise son will delight in him.
Let*ln your father and mother have joy, and*ln let her who gave birth to you rejoice.
My*pn son, give me your heart, and*ln let your eyes observe my ways.
For*ln a prostitute is a deep pit, and*ln a wayward woman is a narrow well;
indeed,*ln she sets an ambush like a robber and*ln increases the number of unfaithful people.
Who*pn has woe? Who has sorrow? Who*ln has conflicts? Who has complaints? Who*ln has wounds for no reason? Who*ln has red eyes?
Those*ln who linger over wine; those*ln who go looking for mixed wine.
Don’t*ln gaze at wine because it is red, because*ln it gleams in the cup and*ln goes down smoothly.
In*ln the end it bites like a snake and*ln stings like a viper.
Your*ln eyes will see strange things, and*ln you will say absurd things.
You’ll*ln be like someone sleeping out at sea or*ln lying down on the top of a ship’s mast.
“They*ln struck me, but I feel no pain! They*ln beat me, but I didn’t know it! When*ln will I wake up? I’ll*ln look for another drink.”
